From: Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference
FuncDef: To configure the port clocking mode for the 1000BASE-T transceivers, use the **clock** command in interface configuration mode. To return to the default settings,use the **no** form of this command.
CLIs: clock { auto | active [ prefer ] | passive [ prefer ] }

ParaDef.Info: (Optional) Negotiates the specified mode with the far end of the link.

ExtraInfo: This command is supported on the 1000BASE-T transceivers only.If the clock mode of the near end of a link does not match the clock mode of the far end, the line protocol does not come up.The active and passive clock status is determined during the auto negotiation process before the transmission link is established.The **clock** command supports the following configurations:•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**auto**—Auto negotiates with the far end of the link but preference is given to the active-clock switch.•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**active**—Uses a local clock to determine transmitter-operation timing.•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**passive**—Recovers the clock from the received signal and uses the recovered clock to determine transmitter-operation timing.•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**active prefer**—Auto negotiates with the far end of the link but preference is given to the active-clock switch.•![](/c/dam/en/us/td/i/templates/blank.gif)**passive prefer**—Auto negotiates with the far end of the link but preference is given to the passive-clock switch.Enter the **show running-config interface** command to display the current clock mode.Enter the **show interfaces** command to display the clock mode that is negotiated by the firmware.
